NewsLine.NewsLineText: MARKETS-BRAZIL (PICTURE):Brazil markets hit as leftist gains for presidency

body.p: By Todd Benson

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Brazil's embattled financial markets took a pounding early on Monday after a fresh opinion poll over the weekend stoked investors' fears that a leftist may be elected president within two weeks' time.

The country's currency, the real, sank 4.2 percent to 3.555 per dollar in thin but volatile trade, slipping below its lowest ever closing level of 3.47, and nearing its historic intraday low of 3.605, both set on July 31. The beleaguered real has now shed nearly 35 percent of its value against the greenback so far in 2002.

Stocks also fell sharply early on Monday, with the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange's benchmark Bovespa index plunging 4.17 percent to 9,186.03 points, dragged down by hefty losses across the boards. The stock market has fallen 32 percent so far this year.
"From the market's point of view, the Datafolha poll over the weekend confirmed the worst possible scenario," said Sergio Machado, treasury director at Banco Fator in Sao Paulo.

The poll, released late Saturday, showed the left-wing front-runner Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva extending his lead to 25 percentage points over market favorite Jose Serra, a distant No. 2 in the polls. The results fueled speculation that the Workers' Party candidate may be on track to winning the election in one round of voting on Oct. 6.
If no candidate garners the sum of the other contenders' votes plus one on Oct. 6, the top two vote-getters go into runoff Oct. 27.

Lula, a former union leader making his fourth bid for the presidency, saw his support among voters surge 4 percentage points to 44 percent in the Datafolha poll, while Serra, the candidate supported by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's ruling coalition, slipped to 19 percent from 21 percent.
The survey also showed former Rio de Janeiro state Gov. Anthony Garotinho, who defines himself to the left of Lula, edging up 1 point to 15 percent, leaving him within striking distance of Serra.
"Lula on the rise, Serra falling and Garotinho climbing is the last thing markets want," said Machado.

Though Lula has toned down his past socialist rhetoric and pledged to pursue fiscal austerity and sound macroeconomic policies, investors fear the former metalworker could face difficulties managing Latin America's largest economy and its burgeoning $260 billion public debt.
Instead they prefer Serra, whom they see as the most likely candidate to forge ahead with the market-friendly reforms of the Cardoso era.

On Friday, Brazil's markets broke a week-long losing streak after a separate poll by the Ibope Institute showed Lula falling slightly to 39 percent of voters' support, raising hopes that Serra can force a run-off ballot on Oct. 27.
STOCKS SLUMP
The poll jitters, coupled with slumping share prices on Wall Street, were also taking their toll on Brazil's stock market on Monday, traders said.

Among the day's most active stocks was market bellwether Tele Norte Leste Participacoes, or Telemar, whose shares tumbled 4.53 percent to 23.20 reais. Telemar stock accounts for about 14 percent of the Bovespa index.
Another actively traded stock taking a hit was state-owned oil giant Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, whose shares fell 4.58 percent to 41.70 reais.

One of the few standouts on the upside was paper and pulp company Aracruz Celulose SA, whose stock price rose 2.6 percent to 5.53 reais. As a major exporter, Aracruz shares tend to get a lift from a weaker local currency.
With a Lula victory appearing increasingly likely, investors said markets were beginning to look for signs of who would take the reins of Brazil's economy in a Workers' Party administration.

"Now people are itching to know who would make up Lula's economic team to see if their market credentials are credible or not," said Pedro Thomazoni, treasury director at Lloyds TSB in Sao Paulo. "Until that happens, markets are going to remain under pressure."
